Dear Jeana Koerber:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title & (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Section policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
Description intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 10/18/24, a youth was being aggressive towards a staff
member. The youth would swing their arms at the staff member
and the staff member slapped the youth's arms away rather than
blocking the arms. The youth has a red mark on the outer middle
left forearm, but it is no longer red.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 10/21/24.
Complainant reported the incident occurred during dinner on
10/18/24. Complainant reported Youth A was at the table eating
but kept getting up from his seat. Complainant reported each of
the three times Youth A got up from his seat, he approached Staff
1 and began swinging his arms and trying to hit Staff 1.
Complainant reported each of the three separate times this
occurred, Staff 1 slapped Youth A’s middle-outer forearm instead
of blocking his attacks like staff are taught to do. After the second
occurrence, Complainant reported she intervened and told Staff 1
he could not slap Youth A but could block him using the skills they
learned. Complainant reported Staff 1 did not respond to the
redirect or ask for further direction as to how to handle the
situation. Complainant reported after Staff 1 hit Youth A the third
time, Youth A eloped from the dining room and entered the hearth
room. Complainant reported Staff 1 followed Youth A to the hearth
room and Complainant stayed with the other youth in the dining
room. Complainant reported after the incident, she met with Staff
2 (lead staff) and told her what happened. Complainant reported
Staff 2 contacted Supervisor 1 for direction as to what to do, while
Complainant filled out an incident report. Complainant reported
Supervisor 1 came in to talk to Staff 1, and then Staff 1 left with
his belongings. Complainant reported after the incident, Youth A
had a red mark on his forearm, but it was gone approximately 30-
40 minutes afterwards.
Youth A is non-verbal and could not be interviewed. He was
observed on 10/24/24 at the facility and no concerns were noted.
2

Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/24/24. Supervisor 1 reported on 10/18/24 she received a call
from Staff 2 asking what needed to be done regarding an incident
of inappropriate safety care by Staff 1. Supervisor 1 reported she
called Supervisor 2 and Chief Administrator to determine what
other steps she needed to take. The immediate safety plan they
implemented was Staff 1 could no longer supervise Youth A.
Supervisor 1 reported she went to the facility to address the
situation further, and interviewed Complainant and Cook to
determine what happened. Supervisor 1 reported she saw Youth
A and he no longer had red marks on his forearm. Supervisor 1
then met with Staff 1 and informed him he was suspended for the
incident pending investigation. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 was
upset and stated he didn’t know why this was happening because
he didn’t understand what he did wrong.
Cook was interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/24/24.
Cook reported during dinner on 10/18/24, Youth A was escalated,
and Staff 1 seemed frustrated by having to continuously tell Youth
A to sit down. Cook reported she did not see Staff 1 slap Youth A
because she was in the kitchen. Cook reported Staff 1 frequently
talks to Youth A like a dog. Cook reported Staff 1 is very direct,
and shows no emotion, no kindness, no empathy or respect to
youth at the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 11/8/24. Staff 1 reported
on 6/18/24, he and Complainant were assigned to supervise youth
while they were eating dinner. Staff 1 reported he was specifically
responsible for supervising Youth A. Staff 1 reported Youth A is
prone to self-exposure of his private parts, so part of Youth A’s
behavior plan is to be prompted every 10-15 seconds to cover
himself if he is exposing himself. Staff 1 reported Youth A was
eating dinner and was constantly exposing himself. Staff 1
reported he kept prompting Youth A to cover himself, “put it away”,
etc. like he is supposed to, but Youth A would not stop. Staff 1
reported he was very frustrated. Staff 1 reported on three different
occasions, Youth A got up and aggressed at Staff 1 by hitting,
pushing, and/or choking him. Staff 1 reported he used the Safety
Care protocol to block the attacks. Staff 1 reported he continued to
use that method and continued to block Youth A’s aggression by
pushing Youth A’s hands and arms away from him, and then
retreating. Staff 1 reported he blocked Youth A’s assaults by
pushing his arms away, but never slapped him. Staff 1 reported
after the second time he blocked Youth A’s assaults, Complainant
came over to Staff 1 and told him they’re not supposed to slap the
youth. Staff 1 reported the sounds of clapping or slapping heard
3

by others were because Youth A was slapping Staff 1, not the
other way around. Staff 1 reported he did not respond to
Complainant because he was concerned Youth A was going to
attack him again. Staff 1 reported he conducted himself as he was
trained. Staff 1 reported after the third time Youth A assaulted him,
Youth A sat back down to eat and continued to expose himself.
Staff 1 reported he continued to prompt Youth A not to expose
himself, and eventually Youth A got up and left the dining room.
Staff 1 reported his level of vigilance at the facility has heightened
due to the level of aggression he’s received from other youth over
the course of him working there (i.e. bites, scratches, a
concussion).
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Agency response strategy dated 10/19/24 from Chief
Administrator notes Staff 1 is suspended pending the
investigation.
• Incident Report dated 10/18/24 is consistent with
Complainant’s interview.
• Restraint and Seclusion Policy states staff may only utilize
procedures in which they are trained and certified.
• Safety Care Protective Shuffle notes if a person engages in
dangerous behavior towards you, this provides a way to
safely move away. The upper position should be both
hands up in front of your face, palms out, fingers and
thumbs together, forearms approximately vertical. Hold
them up to protect yourself without actively blocking or
striking.
• Discipline and Behavior Management policy states staff are
not allowed to hit, strike, throw, kick, pull, or push a youth
on any part of their body.
• Staff 1 has one disciplinary record in his employee file from
8/16/24 stating he did not use safety care appropriately, as
he utilized an improper grab with a youth. Staff 1 was
trained in Safety Care on 7/18/24 and completed a re-
training on 8/17/24.
Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted and
documentation reviewed, Staff 1 had inappropriate contact with
Youth A as Complainant reported Staff 1 slapped Youth A multiple
times, and Staff 1 admitted to pushing Youth A’s arms away from
4

him. Neither of these are approved techniques trained by the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
